'''Little Solsbury Hill''' (more commonly known as '''Solsbury Hill''') is a small flat-topped hill and the site of an [[Iron Age]] [[hill fort]]. It is located above the village of [[Batheaston]] in [[Somerset]], England. The hill rises to {{convert|625|ft|m|0}} above the [[River Avon, Bristol|River Avon]], which is just over {{convert|1|mi|km|0}} to the south, and gives views of the city of [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] and the surrounding area. It is within the [[Cotswolds]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]].
The hill is one of several possible locations of the [[Battle of Badon]] and shows the remains of a medieval field system. In the 19th century part of the hill was quarried. It was acquired by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] in 1930. The hill was the inspiration of the [[Peter Gabriel]] song "[[Solsbury Hill (song)|Solsbury Hill]]" which was recorded in 1977. A small [[turf maze]] was cut into the turf by protesters during the widening of the [[A46 road|A46]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://heritageaction.wordpress.com/2010/03/22/focus-on-little-solsbury-hillfort/ |title=Focus on Little Solsbury Hillfort|publisher=The Heritage Journal|date=22 March 2010|accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref>
==Etymology==
It is sometimes misspelled as ''Salisbury'', or ''Solisbury'', perhaps because of confusion with [[Salisbury Plain]] (a plateau in southern England), or the city of [[Salisbury]]. Salisbury and Solsbury can be difficult to distinguish in speech, as Salisbury is often pronounced "Saulsbury" and sometimes the "a" in "Salisbury" is pronounced as an "o", and the "i" is [[elided]], making the pronunciations of the two words practically identical.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bowles|first=W.L.|title=Hermes britannicus: A Dissertation on the Celtic Deity Teutates, the Mercurius of Caesar, in Further proof and corroboration of the origin and designation of the great temple at abury in Wiltshire|year=1828|publisher=J.B. Nichols and Son|page=126|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=duWIF4qCYa8C&pg=PA126&lpg=PA126&dq=Solsbury+Salisbury,+or+Solisbury#v=onepage&q=Solsbury%20Salisbury%2C%20or%20Solisbury&f=false}}</ref> The name, "Solsbury", may be derived from the [[Celtic polytheism|Celtic god]] [[Sulis]], a deity worshipped at the thermal spring in nearby [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/som/vol1/pp219-288 |title=Romano-British Somerset: Part 2, Bath |author=William Page (editor) |publisher=Institute of Historical Research |year=1906 |work=A History of the County of Somerset: Volume 1 |accessdate=29 September 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Vile|first=Nigel|title=Hill is still in tune with the city's Celtic goddess |url=http://www.bathchronicle.co.uk/Hill-tune-city-s-Celtic-goddess/story-15245965-detail/story.html|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=Bath Chronicle|date=16 February 2012}}</ref>
==Geology==
The hill is formed in layers from a variety of [[sedimentary rock]]s of [[Jurassic]] age. In common with the [[Cotswold Hills|Cotswold plateau]] to the north, the summit is formed from rocks ascribed to the Chalfield Oolite Formation. The [[oolite]] together with the Fuller's Earth Formation which underlies it, forms a part of the [[Great Oolite Group]] of rocks of [[Bathonian]] age. Beneath these are, successively, [[Bajocian]] age limestones of the [[Inferior Oolite Group]] and sandstones of the Bridport Sand Formation. The last-named unit forms a part of the [[Lias Group]] of rocks of [[Toarcian]] age. Beneath all of these is the relatively thick Charmouth Mudstone Formation sequence rising from the edge of the valley floor [[alluvium]]. All faces of the hill are subject to large areas of [[landslip]].<ref>British Geological Survey 2011 ''Bath'', England and Wales sheet 265 Bedrock & Superficial Deposits, 1:50,000 (Keyworth, Nottingham: British Geological Survey)</ref>
The {{convert|625|ft|m|0}} high hill is just over {{convert|1|mi|km|0}} to the north of the [[River Avon, Bristol|River Avon]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Hidden Places of Somerset |last=Scott |first=Shane |authorlink= |authors= |year=1995 |publisher=Travel Publishing Ltd |location=Aldermaston |isbn=1-902007-01-8 |page=16 }}</ref>
==Hill fort== [[Image:Solisbury Camp Somerset Map.jpg|thumb|Earthworks at Solsbury Hill]]
[[Hill fort]]s developed in the Late [[Bronze Age|Bronze]] and Early [[Iron Age]], roughly the start of the [[1st millennium BC|first millennium BC]].<ref>{{Cite book|first1=Andrew |last1=Payne |first2=Mark |last2=Corney |first3=Barry |last3=Cunliffe |title=The Wessex Hillforts Project: Extensive Survey of Hillfort Interiors in Central Southern England |publisher=English Heritage |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-873592-85-4 |url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/publications/wessex-hillforts-project/ | page=1}}</ref> The reason for their emergence in Britain, and their purpose, has been a subject of debate. It has been argued that they could have been military sites constructed in response to invasion from continental Europe, sites built by invaders, or a military reaction to social tensions caused by an increasing population and consequent pressure on agriculture.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Sharples |first=Niall M |title=English Heritage Book of Maiden Castle |publisher=B. T. Batsford |year=1991 |location=London |isbn=0-7134-6083-0 | pages=71–72}}</ref>
Solsbury hill was an [[Iron Age]] [[hill fort]] occupied between 300 [[Before Christ|BC]] and 100 BC, comprising a triangular area enclosed by a single ''[[univallate]]'' rampart, faced inside and out with well-built [[dry stone wall]]s and infilled with rubble.<ref>{{cite web|title=Slight Univallate Hillfort 190m North West of Westleigh|url=http://list.english-heritage.org.uk/resultsingle.aspx?uid=1002481|work=National Heritage List for England|publisher=English Heritage|accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref> The rampart was {{convert|20|ft|m|0}} wide and the outer face was at least {{convert|12|ft|m|0}} high. The top of the hill was cleared down to the bedrock, then substantial huts were built with [[wattle and daub]] on a timber-frame.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dowden|first=W.A.|title=Little Solsbury Hill Camp. Report on Excavations of 1955 and 1956|journal=Proceedings of the University of Bristol Speleological Society|volume=18|issue=1|pages=18–29|url=http://www.ubss.org.uk/resources/proceedings/vol8/UBSS_Proc_8_1_18-29.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dowden|first=W.A.|title=Little Solsbury Hill Camp. Report on Excavations of 1958|journal=Proceedings of the University of Bristol Speleological Society|volume=9|issue=3|pages=177–182|url=http://www.ubss.org.uk/resources/proceedings/vol9/UBSS_Proc_9_3_177-182.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> After a period of occupation, some of the huts were burnt down, the rampart was overthrown, and the site was abandoned, never to be reoccupied.<ref>{{cite web|title=Solsbury Hill|url=http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=203323|website=Pastscape|publisher=English Heritage|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tratman|first1=E.K.|title=Little Solsbury Hill Camp|url=http://www.bacas.org.uk/ArticlePdfs/MS1-13-14.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Bath and Camerton Archaeological Society|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> This event is probably part of the [[Belgic]] invasion of Britain in the early part of the 1st century BC.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ciceran|first1=Marissa|title=General History of Hillforts|url=http://istrianet.org/istria/archeology/castellieri/hillfort-history.htm|publisher=Istrianet|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref>
==Later history==
The hill is near the [[Fosse Way]] [[Roman roads|Roman Road]] as it descends [[Bannerdown]] hill into [[Batheaston]] on its way to [[Aquae Sulis]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Codrington|first=Thomas | authorlink =Thomas Codrington|title=Roman Roads in Britain|year=1903|publisher=[[Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge]]|url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Periods/Roman/Topics/Engineering/roads/Britain/_Texts/CODROM/7*.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Castleden|first1=Rodney|title=King Arthur: The Truth Behind the Legend|date=2003|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134373765|page=95|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iAF_AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=Fosse+Way+Solsbury+Hill#v=onepage&q=Fosse%20Way%20Solsbury%20Hill&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Oswin|first1=John|last2=Buettner|first2=Rick|title=Little Solsbury Hill Camp Geophysical Survey Batheaston, Somerset 2012|url=http://bacas.org.uk/Reports/Solsbury%20Report%20web%20final_.pdf|publisher=Bath and Camerton Archaeological Society|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> Solsbury Hill is a possible location of the [[Battle of Badon]], fought between the Britons (under the legendary [[King Arthur]]) and the [[Wessex|Saxons]] c. 496, mentioned by the chroniclers [[Gildas]] and [[Nennius]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Mick|title=The Site of the Battle of Badon: The Case for Bath|url=http://www.historyfiles.co.uk/FeaturesBritain/BritishMountBadon.htm|work=Post-Roman Britain|publisher=The History Files|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Reno|first=Frank D.|title=The Historic King Arthur: Authenticating the Celtic Hero of Post-Roman Britain|year=1996|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-3025-3|page=159|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V4-bzmtrFnwC&pg=PA159&lpg=PA159&dq=Little+Solsbury+Hill+Camp+Dowden#v=onepage&q=Little%20Solsbury%20Hill%20Camp%20Dowden&f=false}}</ref> The hilltop also shows the remains of a medieval or post medieval field system.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oswin|first1=John|last2=Buettner|first2=Rick|title=Geophysics on Solsbury Hill|url=http://www.nsgg.org.uk/meetings/old/nsgg2012/RBuettner_NSGG2012p.pdf|publisher=Bath and Camerton Archeological Society|accessdate=10 March 2014|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Medieval fields (?) with markers Little Solsbury|url=http://idox.bathnes.gov.uk/WAM/doc/262059-Page-39.pdf?extension=.pdf&page=39&id=262059&contentType=application/pdf&location=VOLUME2 |format=PDF|publisher=Bath and North East Somerset Council|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bath and North East Somerset: Local Plan: Strategic Land Availability Assessment: Report of Findings (November,2013): Appendix 1b: Bath Green Belt|format=PDF|page=24|url=http://www.bathnes.gov.uk/sites/default/files/sitedocuments/Planning-and-Building-Control/Planning-Policy/Evidence-Base/SHLAA/shlaa_nov_2013_-_1b_bath_green_belt_assessments.pdf|publisher=Bath and North East Somerset Council|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref>
The hill also has two disused quarries, one quarry listed on the North West side on an 1911 map, and another one listed as an old quarry on the West side in 1885–1900.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/Maps/OS62htm/0814.htm |title=Ordnance Survey 1:10560 County Series 2nd edition (c.1900) Sheet 08 Subsheet 14 |publisher=somerset.gov.uk |accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> It was acquired by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] in 1930.<ref>{{cite web|title=Acquisitions Up to December 2011|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/cs/Satellite?blobcol=urldata&blobheader=application%2Fpdf&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobheadername2=MDT-Type&blobheadername3=Content-Type&blobheadervalue1=inline%3B+filename%3D297%252F965%252Fnt_acquisitions_dec2011-2%252C2.pdf&blobheadervalue2=abinary%3B+charset%3DUTF-8&blobheadervalue3=application%2Fpdf&blobkey=id&blobtable=MungoBlobs&blobwhere=1349117284549&ssbinary=true|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref> People [[Environmental direct action in the United Kingdom#Road protest camps|protesting]] against the building of an [[A46 road|A46]] bypass road<ref>{{cite book |title=Solsbury Hill: Chronicle of a Road Protest |last=Arbib|first=Adrian |authorlink= |authors= |year=2010 |publisher=Bardwell Press |location=Oxford |isbn=978-1-905622-20-7 |page= }}</ref> cut a small [[turf maze]] into the hill,<ref>{{cite web|title=English Turf Labyrinths|url=http://www.labyrinthos.net/photo_library02.html|publisher=Labyrinthos|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> during the construction of the bypass in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Focus on Little Solsbury Hillfort|url=https://heritageaction.wordpress.com/2010/03/22/focus-on-little-solsbury-hillfort/|publisher=The Heritage Journal|accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref> In one day of protests, 11 people, including [[George Monbiot]], were hospitalised as a result of beatings by the security guards.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.monbiot.com/about/ | title=About George Monbiot | publisher=George Monbiot | date=2014 | accessdate=October 17, 2014}}</ref>
==Wildlife== [[File:Solsbury Hill trig - geograph.org.uk - 185021.jpg|thumb|The [[Triangulation station]] on the top of the hill, with the city of Bath in the distance.]] The plants and animals which live on Solsbury Hill reflect the habitat provided by grassland overlying the limestone rock beneath. Specialist plants and animals, some of which are rare species, have adapted to the [[calcareous grassland]]. Most of the landscape is largely unaffected by agriculture as shown by the [[yellow meadow ant]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hill is still in tune with the city's Celtic goddess|url=http://www.bathchronicle.co.uk/Hill-tune-city-s-Celtic-goddess/story-15245965-detail/story.html|accessdate=8 June 2014|publisher=Bath Chronicle|date=16 February 2012}}</ref> Examples of plant species found include [[Lotus corniculatus|bird's foot trefoil]], [[vetch]]es, [[greater knapweed]], [[harebell]]s, [[yarrow]] (''Achillea millefolium''), and [[scabious]]. It is one of a series of flower-rich habitats, which [[Avon Wildlife Trust]] are trying to link together.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Living Landscape: The Bigger Picture|url=http://www.cornwallwildlifetrust.org.uk/Resources/Cornwall%20Wildlife%20Trust/PDF%20Documents/South_West_Wildlife_Trusts_Living_Landscapes_document_2008.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=South West Wildlife Trusts|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> The plants attract a range of insects including: the [[six-spot burnet|six-spotted burnet moth]], [[hummingbird hawk-moth]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Latest sightings|url=http://www.somersetmothgroup.org.uk/portal/p/Latest+Sightings/r/view/s/200907|publisher=Somerset Moth Group|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> and a number of butterflies including [[chalkhill blue]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Species groups with records for 'LITTLE SOLSBURY HILL'|url=https://data.nbn.org.uk/Reports/Sites/GA00034651102/Groups|publisher=NBN Gateway|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> A small population of [[common buzzard]] (''Buteo buteo'') nest in the area.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fisher|first=Graham|title=Upper Swainswick — Little Solsbury Hill — Charmy Down|url=http://walks.walkingworld.com/walk/Upper-Swainswick---Little-Solsbury-Hill---Charmy-Down.aspx|publisher=Walking World|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref> [[Roe deer]] (''Capreolus capreolus''), [[badger]] and [[red fox]] are also seen.<ref>{{cite web|title=Batheaston SHLAA site BES 1 – Hawkers Yard|url=http://www.batheaston.org/uploads/files/pdfs/PMC%20-%20All%20Place-Making%20Toolkits%20WEB%2015%20jan%2014.pdf|publisher=Bath and North East Somerset Council|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref> The [[skylark]] also nests on the hill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rural Fringe: North of Bath|url=http://www.bathnes.gov.uk/environmentandplanning/planning/planningpolicy/localdevelopmentscheme/Pages/Bath%20CW%20CA%20-%20North.aspx|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614213641/http://www.bathnes.gov.uk/environmentandplanning/planning/planningpolicy/localdevelopmentscheme/Pages/Bath%20CW%20CA%20-%20North.aspx|archivedate=14 June 2012|work=Environment and Planning|publisher=Bath and North east Somerset|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
==Cultural references== Solsbury Hill is also the inspiration for rock musician [[Peter Gabriel]]'s first solo [[Solsbury Hill (song)|single]] in 1977.<ref>{{cite web|title=Solsbury Hill by Peter Gabriel|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=393|publisher=Songfacts|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref> A recording of the natural sounds on Solsbury Hill forms the track "A Quiet Moment" on Peter Gabriel's 2011 album, ''[[New Blood (Peter Gabriel album)|New Blood]]'', which precedes the orchestral version of his song.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hear Peter Gabriel's new album 'New Blood'|url=http://www.nme.com/news/peter-gabriel/59580|accessdate=8 June 2014|publisher=New Musical Express|date=3 October 2011}}</ref>
[[The Warlord Chronicles]], a historical fiction trilogy of books, places the site of Mount Badon at Solsbury Hill.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cornwell|first=Bernard|title=Warlord Chronicles|year=2011|publisher=Penguin UK|isbn=978-0-241-96002-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VWDDsjDxmnEC&pg=PT2464&lpg=PT2464&dq=Solsbury+Hill+Warlord+Chronicles#v=onepage&q=Solsbury%20Hill%20Warlord%20Chronicles&f=false}}</ref>
